NEW DELHI: Congress spokesperson Shama Mohamed on late Sunday questioned the leadership of Indian men's national cricket team captain Rohit Sharma . Reacting to India's match against New Zealand in the ongoing Champions Trophy, Shama labelled Rohit "fat" and called him a "mediocre captain"."Rohit Sharma is fat for a sportsman! Needs to lose weight! And of course, the most unimpressive captain India has ever had!" the Congress spokesperson wrote in a social media post. After facing backlash, the Congress leader deleted her post.She went further in another post, questioning Sharma‚Äôs abilities compared to past cricketing legends. "What is so world-class about him when compared to his predecessors like Ganguly, Tendulkar, Dravid, Dhoni, Kohli, Kapil Dev, Shastri & the rest? He is a mediocre captain as well as a mediocre player who got lucky to be the captain of India."Following the backlash, Shama defended her remarks questioning Rohit's decision to promote himself to the opening spot during India's Test match against Australia, a match that the Men in Blue ultimately lost."Didn't he move KL Rahul to bat at number 3 at the MCG Test & put himself at number 1 which backfired totally ! Wasn't that a selfish move ? Because of that Shubam Gill was out of the XI . Didn't we lose the last World Cup which took place in Ahmedabad? I have compared him to our previous captains," she wrote in another post.Speaking to the news agency ANI, Shama clarified that her remarks were "generic" and were not intended to shame the captain of the Indian men's cricket team. Further defending her comments, she said that, in her opinion, "sportspersons should be fit," and added that she was being "attacked for no reason" over her statements."It was a generic tweet about the fitness of a sportsperson. It was not body-shaming. I always believed a sportsperson should be fit, and I felt he was a bit overweight, so I just tweeted about that," she said."I have been attacked for no reason. When I compared him with previous captains, I put in a statement. I have the right. What is wrong in saying? It is a democracy," she added.BJP‚Äôs Shehzad Poonawalla was quick to respond, taking a dig at the Congress party's electoral failures. "Those who have lost 90 elections under the captaincy of Rahul Gandhi are calling the captaincy of Rohit Sharma unimpressive!" he remarked.Poonawalla also defended Sharma‚Äôs track record, referencing his recent achievements. "I guess six ducks in Delhi and 90 election losses is impressive, but winning the T20 World Cup isn‚Äôt! Rohit has a brilliant track record as captain, by the way!"Meanwhile, on the field, India secured a crucial victory over New Zealand, winning by 44 runs to top Group A. Shreyas Iyer‚Äôs composed 79 and Varun Chakravarthy‚Äôs five-wicket haul helped India set up a semifinal clash against Australia in the Champions Trophy.

Shama labelled Rohit "fat" and called him a "mediocre captain" After facing backlash, the Congress leader deleted her post. On the field, India secured a crucial victory over New Zealand, winning by 44 runs.

Article Title: Virat Kohli leads India to Champions Trophy final with victory over Australia
Article Text:
Chase master scores measured 84 to fashion thrilling win over Australia; Rahul,

too chip in as India make final



Stay tuned for the IND vs AUS Live Score and follow real-time match updates. Get the latest Cricket Live Score and stay ahead with every ball.



DUBAI: It was a six which revived the sweet memories of the maximum that MS Dhoni struck at the Wankhede Stadium in the final to deal India's victory over Sri Lanka in the 2011 World Cup.Skipping down the track to Glenn Maxwell, KL Rahul finished off India's memorable 265-run chase against mighty, but depleted Australia , which came with 11 balls to spare, in style, sending the ball over long-on in the 49th over. Letting out a celebratory shriek, Rahul, often under the lens for being preferred over Rishabh Pant in India's ODI side as a 'keeper-batter, Rahul proved his worth when it mattered, stroking a quickfire 42 not out (34b, 2x4, 2x6) that hastened India's charge, along with Hardik Pandya 's wonderful cameo (28, 24b, 1x4, 3x6) that saw the allrounder smash back-to-back sixes off Adam Zampa in the 47th over, and a 106m giant hit off Tanveer Sangha.The main hero of India's memorable five-wicket win over Australia in the semifinal of the 2025 ICC Champions Trophy at the Dubai International Stadium on Tuesday night was, of course, Virat Kohli , who, reserving his best for the big occasion, slammed a magnificent 84 (98b, 5x4) Having made it to their third Champions Trophy final in a row and fifth overall, India will thus play the winner of the second semifinal between South Africa and New Zealand at Lahore on Wednesday, in the summit clash here on Sunday.Does the occasion present either of the two Indian batting titans-Kohli and captain Rohit Sharma , with the perfect occasion to draw curtains on their international career? We will wait and see.The victory, to some extent, erased the pain of millions of Indian cricket-lovers after Australia had downed Rohit Sharma & Co by six wickets in the final of the 2023 ODI World Cup at the Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad. Just like India, Rahul, who had crawled to a 107-ball 66 that day, too deleted the bad memories of that day on Tuesday night.Even as there were the usual straight drives, pulls and cuts, the hallmark of this Kohli innings was his ability to rotate the strike and swift running between the wickets, which kept the scoreboard moving. The 36-year-old enjoyed being on the right side of lady luck too, as he was let off on 51 in the 26th over by Glenn Maxwell, usually a brilliant fielder, at short mid-off off left-arm spinner Cooper Connolly, playing in place of injured Matthew Short.Giving wings to India's innings, Kohli put on 91 in 111 balls for the third wicket with Shreyas Iyer (45, 62b, 3x4), before the Mumbaikar was bowled while trying to cut an Adam Zampa delivery. Kohli then added 44 in 52 balls for the fourth wicket with Axar Patel (27, 30b, 1x4, 1x6) and 47 in 46 balls for the fifth wicket with Rahul to take India closer to the final.Kohli walked in after India lost Shubman Gill (8) in the fifth over when the in-form batter was bowled, getting an inside edge while trying to pull left-arm pacer Ben Dwarshuis. Soon, skipper Rohit Sharma's (28, 29b, 4x4, 1x6), luck ran out-he was dropped twice-when the 37-year-old was trapped lbw while missing a sweep off left-arm spinner Cooper Connolly, brought in by Australia for injured opener Matthew Short.Earlier, skipper Steve Smith (73, 96b, 4x4, 1x6) and 'keeper-bat Alex Carey (61, 57b, 8x4, 1x6) slammed sublime half-centuries, but another fine bowling performance by India, led by veteran pacer Mohammed Shami (three for 48 in 10 overs) helped them bowl out Australia to a below par 264 in 49.3 overs.While there were many small partnerships during Australia's innings, the world champions paid for some poor shot selection by their batters and lacked that one big stand, which meant that finished 20-25 runs short on what looks to be a batting paradise. Travis Head (39 off 33 balls, 5x4, 2x6), Marnus Labuschagne (29, 36b, 2x4, 1x6) and Josh Inglis (11) all frittered away good starts and were out against the run of play. Had any of them got going, India would've been staring at a 300-plus total.Electing to bat first on a good batting wicket, Australia suffered an early jolt when opener Connolly was caught superbly by 'keeper KL Rahul off Shami in the third over for a nine-ball duck. Dropped by Shami off the latter's own bowling in the first legal ball of the match, Head gave India's cricket fans some early jitters in the match by unleashing some delightful shots which reminded you of his blistering 137 off 120 balls in the 2023 World Cup final. India's old nemesis, the opener launched a counterattack to put the Aussies, flicking Hardik Pandya for a six in the fourth over and hitting three successive fours off Shami in the fifth over, before coming down the track to dispatch Kuldeep Yadav for a six over the bowler's head to put the Aussies in the driver's seat.However, just as the left-hander looked set for another big knock against his favourite opponents, having added 50 in just 32 balls for the second wicket with Smith, 'mystery' spinner Varun Chakravarthy , coming off a match-winning five for 42 in the last match against New Zealand at the same venue, netted the big fish off his first ball in the match, having him caught by Shubman Gill, who sprinted from long off to pull off a good grab. Collectively, the whole of India heaved a sigh of relief!Shami eventually removed Smith, who had a brain fade as he charged at the bowler, looking to tonk a quick full toss, but was castled in the 37th over. Glenn Maxwell did what Maxwell does-thrashed a six off Axar Patel to mid-wicket, before the bowler had his revenge in the same over, as the batter was bowled while trying to a big shot. Still Australia would have made a bigger score if not for a brilliant direct hit by Shreyas Iyer, which resulted in Carey falling short of his crease while going for the second run.Mixing the pace of his deliveries and being pinpoint accurate with his yorkers, Shami, who had taken five for 53 in the first match of the tournament at this venue against Bangladesh, was the best of the Indian bowlers.
Article Summary: India beat Australia by five wickets in ICC Champions Trophy semifinal. Virat Kohli top scored with 84 while KL Rahul hit 42 not out. India will play South Africa or New Zealand in Sunday's final in Lahore. Australia bowled out for 264 in 49.3 overs.

Article Title: 'Main maar raha tha na': KL Rahul on Virat Kohli's dismissal against Australia - watch video
Article Text:
Virat Kohli and KL Rahul during the ICC Champions Trophy 2025 semi-final match against Australia in Dubai. (ANI)

Gautam Gambhir hits out at critics after India beat Australia to reach Champions Trophy final

Virat Kohli steers India to third consecutive Champions Trophy final

During a drinks break in the 40th over of India's chase, KL Rahul spoke with Virat Kohli , appearing to encourage him to stay at the crease until the end. With India requiring 65 runs from 60 balls against Australia on Tuesday, KL Rahul took on the role of aggressor in this Champions Trophy semi-final in Dubai.Rahul quickly scored a four and a six in his next five deliveries to ease the pressure on Kohli. He then rotated the strike to Kohli when India needed 40 runs from 45 balls, with Kohli 16 runs away from his 52nd ODI century.Kohli, despite being in control throughout the chase, attempted an unnecessary slog sweep against Adam Zampa and was caught at long-on. This uncharacteristic dismissal visibly frustrated KL Rahul at the non-striker's end."Main maar raha that naa (I was going after the bowling)," Rahul told Kohli as he walked past him.In the dressing room, coach Gautam Gambhir was also left visibly upset and mumbled something to the support staff and players seated alongside him.After the match, KL Rahul revealed his conversation with Kohli. "When I walked in and when I played 10-12 balls I told him that you're the batter that needs to go on and be there till the end. And let me try and hit or let me try and take one chance an over. Because like you said we only needed 6 runs and over. But 6 runs and over on that wicket seemed like 8-8.5. So, you had to take one chance and over, one boundary or one six," Rahul told Star Sports."So, I told him that I will do that and why don't you just rotate the strike and be there because you're the set batter and it might be harder. If you get out another set batter comes it becomes a lot more harder. But yeah, he felt like it was in his range to hit and yeah he didn't time it well."Rahul maintained his composure and finished unbeaten with 42 runs from 34 balls, securing the victory with a six in the 49th over's first ball. This win advanced India to their fifth Champions Trophy final. Hardik Pandya contributed with a quick 28 runs from 24 balls before his dismissal.Despite the one mistimed shot, Kohli's performance was exceptional. He formed a crucial 91-run partnership for the third wicket with Shreyas Iyer, who scored 45 runs, after the early dismissals of Rohit Sharma (28) and Shubman Gill (9).Although Australia were missing key players, India hadn't defeated them in ICC tournament knockouts since the 2011 World Cup quarterfinal.Kohli effectively handled leg-spinner Adam Zampa, who had previously troubled him. He utilised pull shots and drives between sweeper cover and mid-wicket for consistent scoring.After losing both Iyer and Axar Patel (27) in quick succession, Kohli reached his fifty in 53 balls. Glenn Maxwell dropped a catch when Kohli was on 51 off Cooper Connolly's bowling.Kohli's innings ended when India needed 40 runs to win, as he hit the ball to Ben Dwarshuis at long-on off Zampa's bowling.
Article Summary: Virat Kohli was 16 runs away from his 52nd ODI century. He attempted an unnecessary slog sweep against Adam Zampa and was caught at long-on. This uncharacteristic dismissal visibly frustrated KL Rahul at the non-striker's end. After the match, Rahul revealed his conversation with Kohli.
